Notices

by Roy John
Team Leader, Registration Services – Environmental, Health and Safety Systems


Bonnie MacKenzie, Regional Director General, Public Works and Governmetn Services Canada (centre) presents certificates of appreciation to several members of the Esquimalt Graving Dock EMS steering committee: (Left to Right) Jim Sandwith, Peninsula Waste Water Services Ltd; Malcolm Barker, Victoria Shipyards; Gordon Safarik, Esquimalt Dry Dock Company; and Peter Brennan of Jenkins Marine.

The Canadian General Standards Board has recently registered the Esquimalt Graving Dock, the largest fixed-foundation civilian dry dock on the West Coast of North America, to ISO 14001. Located in a suburb of Victoria, British Columbia, the dock is owned and operated by Public Works and Government Services Canada (PWGSC), but all the shipbuilding and repairs are done by private companies.

ISO 14001 registration has come about because in 1999 the dock's management and tenants agreed that an organized approach was necessary to address environmental issues associated with industry activities.

Recognizing that the success of the project required the participation and support of a number of independent organizations, PWGSC began by forming an environmental committee of all the affected parties. The PWGSC staff persuaded the ship-repair firms that creating an EMS was right for both moral and business reasons. Making this change in an industry centuries old and very conservative was a major accomplishment in itself. Once this had been achieved the PWGSC environmental staff worked on designing a coherent EMS.

The proposed environmental management system took into account PWGSC's unique situation of being the owner and operator of the dock, but not the ship-repair service provider. It gave operating protocols for all of the PWGSC functions – providing water, steam, power, air as well as the physical facilities. In addition it included mechanisms to ensure that the dock's tenants repsected Esquimalt's environmental needs.

To increase awareness and goodwill, the pre-audit training sessions provided to PWGSC employees were made available to all of the dock's tenants. This not only provided technical information to the people working on site, but also created a strong team spirit.

The Canadian General Standards Board's August 2001 audit focused primarily on two issues. One involved the division of activities between the facility operator (PWGSC) and the service providers, and the need for a dividing line between responsibility and influence to be clearly established. The other concerned the difficulty in defining the scope of the entity to be registered. It took an effort to produce a scope that encompassed the broad and somewhat diffuse structure at Esquimalt Graving Dock while keeping within the limits of PWGSC's management control.

Typcially an audit report identifies deficiencies. Only rarely does it include congratulations, but this was the case with the Esquimalt Graving Dock. The dock's management and tenants were applauded for their outstanding team effort, in producing a truly shared environmental management system.

Achieving ISO 14001 regsitration demonstrates that PWGSC is a good corporate environmental citizen. The management discipline imposed by the standard will allow the staff to retain control over the environmental issues despite the consistently changing nature of the marine repair-business. The Esquimalt Graving Dock was one of the first federal organizations to meet the requirements of ISO 14001, and one of only three large shipyards in the world to achieve this designation.

The Canadian General Standards Board extends its congratuations to the Esquimalt Graving Dock's management and tenants on achieving ISO 14001 registration.

Source: Calibre, Spring 2002, Volume 7, No. 1
